channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Snow Drought in the West Reaches Record Levels
item.description: Warm temperatures and extremely low snowfall threaten water resources for the year.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins

item.title: Jeff Bezos’s Rocket Company Blue Origin Pauses Space Tourism to Focus on the Moon
item.description: The New Shepard rocket from Blue Origin, which brought 92 people on trips to the edge of space, will cease flying for at least two years as the company prioritizes NASA contracts.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: With AlphaGenome, Researchers Are Using A.I. to Decode the Human Blueprint
item.description: AlphaGenome is a leap forward in the ability to study the human blueprint. But the fine workings of our DNA are still largely a mystery.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Volker Steger/Science Source
item.media:description: DNA electrophoresis in a lab. Scientists at Google DeepMind have trained their A.I on a vast wealth of molecular data, enabling it to make predictions about thousands of genes.

item.title: Rare Albatross Coasts Above California Waters Far From Home
item.description: The unexpected sighting of a waved albatross, which was thousands of miles from its typical range, earned it a label ornithologists reserve for the unexpected: an avian “vagrant.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Melody Baran/University of California-San Diego-Scripps Institution of Oceanography, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A rare waved albatross was spotted off the coast of Point Piedras Blancas, Calif., this month.

item.title: You Wouldn’t Want to Butt Heads With This Small Dinosaur
item.description: A newly discovered raptor had a knobby bump on its head, suggesting that, like some larger dinosaurs, it engaged in competitive head bashing.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: How to View the Artemis II Moon Launch
item.description: The first crewed mission around the moon in more than 50 years is coming up. Here’s how to see it at sites in and around the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.media:credit: Cassandra Klos for The New York Times
item.media:description: NASA is preparing to send four astronauts on its lunar Artemis II mission. Above, the scene on Jan. 17 during the rollout at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

item.title: 430,000-Year-Old Wooden Tools Are the Oldest Ever Found
item.description: The finding, along with the discovery of a 500,000-year-old hammer made of bone, indicates that our human ancestors were making tools even earlier than archaeologists thought.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: A New Way to Flirt: Dazzle Potential Mates With Patterns Invisible to Humans
item.description: Cuttlefish attract prospective sexual partners by creating a pattern on their skin, based on the orientation of light waves.
item.dc:creator: Kate Golembiewski
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Sonic Booms and Seismic Waves Can Reveal Where Space Junk Crash-Lands
item.description: The sensors used to listen for earthquakes could help protect people from the hazards created by falling spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: Robin George Andrews

item.title: When the Doctor Needs a Checkup
item.description: The physician work force is aging fast, and some hospitals now require that older clinicians undergo testing for cognitive decline. Many have resisted.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.media:credit: Eugenia Mello

item.title: Morris Waxler, F.D.A. Official Who Switched Stance on Lasik, Dies at 88
item.description: While at the federal agency, he approved the laser device for eye surgery but later warned of its potential to cause harm.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: A Predictor of a Good Social Life? Your Parents.
item.description: A decades-long study suggested that close relationships with family members during teenage years could lead to a rich network of friendships in adulthood.
item.dc:creator: Emily Baumgaertner Nunn
item.media:credit: Alamy
item.media:description: High social connection in adulthood was more than twice as common among people who had the strongest family ties in youth, compared with those who had the weakest.

item.title: D.O.E. Panel to Question Climate Science Was Unlawful, Judge Rules
item.description: The researchers produced a report that was central in a Trump administration effort to stop regulating climate pollution.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Reuters
item.media:description: The judge ruled that Energy Secretary Chris Wright violated the law when he handpicked researchers to work in secret to produce a government report on global warming.

item.title: Grids Are Surviving the Storm. But the Next 5 Years Could Be Rough.
item.description: A group that monitors the U.S. electricity system warns that grid reliability is “worsening” and blackout risks are rising for millions of people.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A crew working to restore power in Austin, Texas, in 2021, after a major storm.

item.title: Drilling Through the Thwaites Glacier for Clues to Its Melting
item.description: A team hopes to place instruments in the waters beneath the colossal Thwaites Glacier, with the help of a drill that uses hot water to punch through ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Algae Growth on Greenland’s Ice Contributes to Melting, Studies Show
item.description: New studies show how algae grows on ice and snow, creating “dark zones” that exacerbate melting in the consequential region.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey

item.title: Kennedy Overhauls Federal Autism Panel in His Own Image
item.description: The new panel, which advises the government on research and service priorities for people with autism, includes many members who have argued that vaccines cause the disorder.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Although the panel only serves an advisory function, many longtime autism advocates and researchers were alarmed by some of the new panel members.

item.title: Genes May Control Your Longevity, However Healthily You Live
item.description: A new study suggests that those with long-lived families probably have the best prospects of making it to a very old age.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Svalbard Polar Bears Are Getting Fatter (for Now), Study Finds
item.description: Seals favored by Svalbard bears are becoming easier to hunt as ice declines, a study found. But researchers say the situation may be temporary.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

item.title: Why a New Mexico Developer Quit Natural Gas
item.description: For John Moscato, a land developer in Las Cruces, N.M., installing gas lines at new home sites was “an ongoing headache.” Ditching gas saved him money.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times

item.title: Dutch Court Orders Netherlands to Protect Bonaire From Climate Change
item.description: Bonaire, a Dutch overseas territory, deserves the same protections as Europe, the ruling said. The decision adds to a growing body of precedent worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Piroschka Van De Wouw/Reuters
item.media:description: Marieke Vellekoop, director of Greenpeace Netherlands, center, with plaintiffs from Bonaire in court in The Hague in October.

item.title: Texas Sues Delaware Nurse Practitioner for Mailing Abortion Pills to the State
item.description: The case is the latest action taken by a state with an abortion ban against providers in states that support abortion rights.
item.dc:creator: Pam Belluck
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Debra Lynch, a nurse practitioner in Delaware, was sued by the Texas attorney general, who accused her of prescribing and shipping abortion pills to residents of Texas in violation of that state’s abortion ban.

item.title: Camping on Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: After working and camping for a week on Thwaites Glacier, scientists were ready to start drilling into the ice, if only the weather would let them.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Pillbugs Are Getting Top Dollar Online. Poachers Have Noticed.
item.description: A robust, largely unregulated online trade in isopods could pose a serious threat to some vulnerable species, scientists warn.
item.dc:creator: Madeline Shaw
item.media:credit: Nicky Bay
item.media:description: The Cuban Spiky, Pseudarmadillo spinosus, is one of the isopods most prized by hobbyists. A few live specimens can sell for hundreds of dollars.

item.title: Gladys West, Unsung Figure in Development of GPS, Dies at 95
item.description: As a Navy mathematician in the 1950s and beyond, she played an unheralded but foundational role in making possible the global satellite-based mapping system.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Peter H. Duesberg, 89, Renowned Biologist Turned H.I.V. Denialist, Dies
item.description: His pioneering work on the origins of cancer was later overshadowed by his contrarian views, notably his rejection of the established theory that H.I.V. causes AIDS.
item.dc:creator: Faye Flam
item.media:credit: Roger Ressmeyer/Corbis — VCG, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Peter H. Duesberg in 1985, holding a tray of petri dishes containing cultured cancer cells. In the late 1960s, he discovered the first known cancer-causing gene, or oncogene.

item.title: A Shift for NOAA’s Surveys: From Science to Mining
item.description: A $20 million agency project will aid companies prospecting the sea for critical minerals.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler and Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ship charted to explore the seabed in the Gulf of Mexico in 2021.

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Michigan Sues Oil Giants, Saying They Collude to Make Energy Costlier
item.description: The lawsuit accuses the companies of raising prices by working against solar and wind power and by downplaying the risks of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: ExxonMobil is among several major companies and groups named in the Michigan lawsuit.

item.title: Radar Scans of Antarctica Offer Clues to What’s Happening on Jupiter’s Moon
item.description: Scientists are using radar to study damaged ice both in Antarctica and, with the help of a NASA spacecraft, on Jupiter’s ocean moon of Europa.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: An engineer aboard the icebreaker Araon prepared a helicopter with ice-penetrating radar for a flight over the Thwaites Glacier.

item.title: U.S Has Officially Withdrawn From the Paris Climate Accord
item.description: The United States is the only country to pull out of the global agreement among nations to fight climate change. European diplomats say the U.S. reputation is suffering.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Paul Ratje for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moves by the Trump administration underline America’s isolation in the effort to control the greenhouse gases, mostly from the burning of fossil fuels, that are dangerously heating the planet.

item.title: Thomas Fogarty, 91, Who Helped Revolutionize Vascular Surgery, Dies
item.description: Drawing on his love of fly-fishing, he developed a balloon catheter that removes blood clots from patients’ limbs in a minimally invasive way. It has saved millions of lives.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman
item.media:credit: Jeff Zelevansky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Dr. Thomas J. Fogarty in 2000 on receiving the Lemelson-M.I.T. Prize for his work in developing medical technologies. He “single-handedly changed the face of cardiovascular surgery,” a colleague said.
